en: "Load up" with the 2nd Bn. 417th Inf. 76 Div.
"Load up" with the 2nd Bn. 417th Inf. 76 Div. -- Paris (France)
Canvas for "Load up" with the 2nd Bn. 417th Inf. 76 Div.

body.value: Cartoon depiction of the Eiffel Tower and France.
Cartoon depiction of a G.I.'s encounter with a prostitute in London.
A cartoon depiction of a child and a woman wearing clogs and a bonnet moving a wagon full of items. They appear to be German refugees.
A military vehicle transporting several G.I.s through heavy precipitation (a mixture of what seems to be hail and rain) in Belgium. The G.I.s have unpleasant/distressed faces.

A cartoonish depiction of a standoff between German and American troops at the Rhine River. It depicts both parties making humorous faces at each other mockingly, with catastrophes and chaos in the background.

A cartoon depiction of several G.I.s huddled around a campfire while precipitation (just rain) falls on them. A G.I. is shown hurriedly taking wood to the flame, and another in the background is shown gathering wood from a building.

A cartoon depiction of a soldier saying, "Give me that P-38" while pointing a rifle at a German soldier's back. The P-38 in question is one of many items taken by G.I.s as souvenirs in the war during their time outside the U.S. These items or souvenirs that soldiers would bring home range from pictures, documents (such as one Book from Hitler's collection at A&M's Sam Houston Sanders Corps of Cadets Center),  and military firearms such as the P-38. The military had issues with souvenir hunting because of several issues:

1. Souvenir hunters often put themselves and their comrades in danger trying to gather such items

2. Valuable information or intelligence could be tampered with or gone

3. The transport of these items could be dangerous

 

Promotion against Souvenir Hunting posted in 1945

Image from https://www.americanrifleman.org/content/the-firearm-war-trophies-of-world-war-ii/

 

Depiction of a Walther P-38, a 9 mm semi-automatic pistol in use since the start of WWII by Nazi Germans

Image from https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/8/86/Walther_P38_(6971798779).jpg

A cartoon depiction of a mother surrounded by malnourished/unhandsome children. The mother herself is wearing clogs and blue clothing, possibly hinting at her as a German during the French Occupation.

The title of the "Load up" map. The title depicts a total of 11 G.I.s in the photo, either operating machinery or in a stationary position, and a large V. The V is a motif most G.I.s used to symbolize the "victory" of the Allied powers in the European front of WWII. The cartoon also comes with a majority of the colors used in the map (light blue, pink, black, and green).

Depictions of Victory come in many forms.

- V

- Morse code ( . . . - )
A cartoon depiction of a military vehicle with several G.I.s passing through a ruined city.
